annotation.text: The ArfGEF GBF-1 Is Required for ER Structure, Secretion and Endocytic Transport in C. elegans
The ArfGEF GBF-1 Is Required for ER Structure, Secretion and Endocytic Transport in C. elegans
The ArfGEF GBF-1 Is Required for ER Structure, Secretion and Endocytic Transport in C. elegans
The ArfGEF GBF-1 Is Required for ER Structure, Secretion and Endocytic Transport in C. elegans
GBF-1 localizes to the cis-Golgi and is part of the t-ER-Golgi elements.
GBF-1 is required for secretion and Golgi integrity.
GBF-1 is required for secretion and Golgi integrity.

In addition, gbf-1(RNAi) causes the ER reticular structure to become dispersed, without destroying ER exit sites (ERES) because the ERES protein SEC-16 was still localized in distinct punctae at t-ER-Golgi units.

In addition, gbf-1(RNAi) causes the ER reticular structure to become dispersed, without destroying ER exit sites (ERES) because the ERES protein SEC-16 was still localized in distinct punctae at t-ER-Golgi units.
Moreover, GBF-1 plays a role in receptor-mediated endocytosis in oocytes, without affecting recycling pathways.

While RAB5-positive early endosomes appear to be less prominent and the RAB-5 levels are reduced by gbf-1(RNAi) in the intestine, RAB-7-positive late endosomes were more abundant and formed aggregates and tubular structures.
Our data suggest a role for GBF-1 in ER structure and endosomal traffic.
Our data suggest a role for GBF-1 in ER structure and endosomal traffic.

In addition, gbf-1(RNAi) causes the ER reticular structure to become dispersed, without destroying ER exit sites (ERES) because the ERES protein SEC-16 was still localized in distinct punctae at t-ER-Golgi units.

In addition, gbf-1(RNAi) causes the ER reticular structure to become dispersed, without destroying ER exit sites (ERES) because the ERES protein SEC-16 was still localized in distinct punctae at t-ER-Golgi units.
Here we analyzed the function of C. elegans PHI-34/GBF-1 and found that it is localized to the cis-Golgi at transitional ER-Golgi elements.
In addition, GBF-1 is required for Golgi maintenance and knockdown of GBF-1 causes a strong defect in ER structure and reduction in secretion, consistent with faulty retrograde transport.
In addition, GBF-1 is required for Golgi maintenance and knockdown of GBF-1 causes a strong defect in ER structure and reduction in secretion, consistent with faulty retrograde transport.
In addition, GBF-1 is required for Golgi maintenance and knockdown of GBF-1 causes a strong defect in ER structure and reduction in secretion, consistent with faulty retrograde transport.

annotation.infon: retrograde vesicle-mediated transport, Golgi to ER|GO:0006890
annotation.text: In addition, GBF-1 is required for Golgi maintenance and knockdown of GBF-1 causes a strong defect in ER structure and reduction in secretion, consistent with faulty retrograde transport.

We also detected defects in endocytosis in gbf-1(RNAi) animals. However, the defect was not obvious at the plasma membrane but rather affected early and more strongly late endosomes. Therefore, we identify a novel role for GBF-1 at endosomes.
Reduction of GBF-1 results in strong developmental defects and a weakened cuticle
Reduction of GBF-1 results in strong developmental defects and a weakened cuticle

Feeding gbf-1 RNAi producing bacteria from L1 stage caused cuticle rupture in the majority of the worms upon reaching adulthood, resulting in a 50 to 80% mortality rate. Moreover, the knockdown caused sterility due to embryonic lethality in the escapers that were able to reach adulthood without bursting (Fig. 1A). Freshly hatched larvae also frequently showed severe abnormalities in their cuticle formation (Fig. 1B).

Feeding gbf-1 RNAi producing bacteria from L1 stage caused cuticle rupture in the majority of the worms upon reaching adulthood, resulting in a 50 to 80% mortality rate. Moreover, the knockdown caused sterility due to embryonic lethality in the escapers that were able to reach adulthood without bursting (Fig. 1A). Freshly hatched larvae also frequently showed severe abnormalities in their cuticle formation (Fig. 1B).

annotation.infon: embryo development ending in birth or egg hatching|GO:0009792
annotation.text: Feeding gbf-1 RNAi producing bacteria from L1 stage caused cuticle rupture in the majority of the worms upon reaching adulthood, resulting in a 50 to 80% mortality rate. Moreover, the knockdown caused sterility due to embryonic lethality in the escapers that were able to reach adulthood without bursting (Fig. 1A). Freshly hatched larvae also frequently showed severe abnormalities in their cuticle formation (Fig. 1B).
gbf-1(RNAi) worms causes multiple development defects.
(A) gbf-1(RNAi) worms have a weakened cuticle.
When fed from hatching on gbf-1(RNAi) bacteria, the majority of the worms died of cuticle bursting upon reaching adulthood.

annotation.infon: embryo development ending in birth or egg hatching|GO:0009792
annotation.text: Although most embryos arrested early in development in gfb-1(RNAi) worms, few larvae could hatch from the eggs.
Although most embryos arrested early in development in gfb-1(RNAi) worms, few larvae could hatch from the eggs. These larvae often displayed severe problems with their cuticle formation.
(C) Worms fed on gbf-1(RNAi) from hatching frequently accumulate liquid filled vacuoles in the body cavity. Furthermore they are sterile (no eggs in the uterus) and their intestine appears 'clear'.

annotation.infon: polar body extrusion after meiotic divisions|GO:0040038
annotation.text: In gbf-1(RNAi) eggs, the extrusion of the second polar body during anaphase II often failed, which can be seen by the presence of 3 nuclei (arrow) in fertilized eggs at pronuclear meeting.
(E) Offspring from worms fed on gbf-1(RNAi) from L3 frequently show problems with cytokinesis which results in unequal distribution of the DNA between cells.

annotation.infon: embryo development ending in birth or egg hatching|GO:0009792
annotation.text: The reduced knockdown of GBF-1 allowed normal production and fertilization of oocytes. Nevertheless this treatment caused an embryonic lethal effect in 60 to 70% of the fertilized oocytes.

annotation.infon: embryo development ending in birth or egg hatching|GO:0009792
annotation.text: The arrested eggs of gbf-1(RNAi) were easily recognized as they were generally highly distorted. We found them to be stretched, rounded-up, and leaking through the egg shell (not shown). This completely disintegrated egg shell resulted in an amorphous mass of cells and membranes in the gonad (Fig. S3B). We also observed defects in polar body extrusion in around 30% of the fertilized oocytes (Fig. 1D). In addition, in a similar percentage of eggs cytokinesis was defective (Fig. 1D).

annotation.infon: polar body extrusion after meiotic divisions|GO:0040038
annotation.text: The arrested eggs of gbf-1(RNAi) were easily recognized as they were generally highly distorted. We found them to be stretched, rounded-up, and leaking through the egg shell (not shown). This completely disintegrated egg shell resulted in an amorphous mass of cells and membranes in the gonad (Fig. S3B). We also observed defects in polar body extrusion in around 30% of the fertilized oocytes (Fig. 1D). In addition, in a similar percentage of eggs cytokinesis was defective (Fig. 1D).

The arrested eggs of gbf-1(RNAi) were easily recognized as they were generally highly distorted. We found them to be stretched, rounded-up, and leaking through the egg shell (not shown). This completely disintegrated egg shell resulted in an amorphous mass of cells and membranes in the gonad (Fig. S3B). We also observed defects in polar body extrusion in around 30% of the fertilized oocytes (Fig. 1D). In addition, in a similar percentage of eggs cytokinesis was defective (Fig. 1D).

The arrested eggs of gbf-1(RNAi) were easily recognized as they were generally highly distorted. We found them to be stretched, rounded-up, and leaking through the egg shell (not shown). This completely disintegrated egg shell resulted in an amorphous mass of cells and membranes in the gonad (Fig. S3B). We also observed defects in polar body extrusion in around 30% of the fertilized oocytes (Fig. 1D). In addition, in a similar percentage of eggs cytokinesis was defective (Fig. 1D).
Taken together, reduction of GBF-1 expression caused severe developmental problems starting already at fertilization.
GBF-1 is important for Golgi integrity

In mature oocytes, GBF-1 localization is closely associated and partially overlapping with the Golgi marker GFP::UGTP-1 [18] (Fig. 2A) and was always found in close proximity to ERES marker SEC-16 [34], confirming cis-Golgi localization (Fig. 2C).

In mature oocytes, GBF-1 localization is closely associated and partially overlapping with the Golgi marker GFP::UGTP-1 [18] (Fig. 2A) and was always found in close proximity to ERES marker SEC-16 [34], confirming cis-Golgi localization (Fig. 2C).

In mature oocytes, GBF-1 localization is closely associated and partially overlapping with the Golgi marker GFP::UGTP-1 [18] (Fig. 2A) and was always found in close proximity to ERES marker SEC-16 [34], confirming cis-Golgi localization (Fig. 2C).
This experiment demonstrates that GBF-1 is present on the cis-face of the Golgi at so-called transitional ER-Golgi elements [34], [39]-[41].
(A) GBF-1 localizes to the Golgi in oocytes.
(A) GBF-1 localizes to the Golgi in oocytes.
GBF-1 partially co-localized with the medial Golgi marker UGTP-1::GFP.
GBF-1 partially co-localized with the medial Golgi marker UGTP-1::GFP.
(B) GBF-1 is part of the Golgi t-ER region in oocytes.
GBF-1 was localized juxtaposed to the ERES marker SEC-16.
GBF-1 was found 'sandwiched' between the Golgi marker UGTP::GFP and ERES marker SEC-16.
GBF-1 was found 'sandwiched' between the Golgi marker UGTP::GFP and ERES marker SEC-16.
(D) agef-1(RNAi) and gbf-1(RNAi) causes the collapse of the Golgi around the nuclear membrane and cell periphery in oocytes.
(D) agef-1(RNAi) and gbf-1(RNAi) causes the collapse of the Golgi around the nuclear membrane and cell periphery in oocytes.
The bottom panel shows an enlargement of a Golgi stack as indicated by a red box. Largely inflated cisternae were observed in both agef-1(RNAi) and gbf-1(RNAi) cells as indicated by asterisks.
The bottom panel shows an enlargement of a Golgi stack as indicated by a red box. Largely inflated cisternae were observed in both agef-1(RNAi) and gbf-1(RNAi) cells as indicated by asterisks.
gbf-1(RNAi) Golgi stacks accumulated a lot of small-sized vesicles as indicated by black arrows.

gbf-1(RNAi) caused the small Golgi foci to aggregate into large structures in at least 80% of the analyzed gonads, mainly around the nuclear membrane and cell-periphery (Fig. 2D), similar to what has been observed previously for agef-1(RNAi) and arf-1.2(RNAi) [3] (Fig. 2D).

agef-1(RNAi) resulted in large inflated cisternae, consistent with a block in secretion at the trans-Golgi [3], while upon gbf-1(RNAi) numerous vesicles accumulated at the cis-Golgi, representing most likely ER-derived COPII vesicles.

agef-1(RNAi) resulted in large inflated cisternae, consistent with a block in secretion at the trans-Golgi [3], while upon gbf-1(RNAi) numerous vesicles accumulated at the cis-Golgi, representing most likely ER-derived COPII vesicles.

agef-1(RNAi) resulted in large inflated cisternae, consistent with a block in secretion at the trans-Golgi [3], while upon gbf-1(RNAi) numerous vesicles accumulated at the cis-Golgi, representing most likely ER-derived COPII vesicles.
Thus, loss of AGEF-1 and GBF-1 affect Golgi morphology in a different manner.
Thus, loss of AGEF-1 and GBF-1 affect Golgi morphology in a different manner.
Because agef-1(RNAi) caused the Golgi cisternae to be inflated, we asked whether this effect could potentially impair the association of GBF-1 with the Golgi.
However, we found that GBF-1 was recruited to the cis-Golgi independently of AGEF-1 (Fig. S2).
The GBF-1 localization to the Golgi is consistent with a block of TGN exit and a block in maturation in agef-1(RNAi) oocytes.
The GBF-1 localization to the Golgi is consistent with a block of TGN exit and a block in maturation in agef-1(RNAi) oocytes.
The GBF-1 localization to the Golgi is consistent with a block of TGN exit and a block in maturation in agef-1(RNAi) oocytes.
gbf-1(RNAi) impairs ER structure but does not affect SEC-16 localization
Since GBF-1 localized in t-ER-Golgi elements and because gbf-1(RNAi) oocytes accumulated vesicles at the ER-Golgi interface, we asked whether loss of GBF-1 would also affect ER morphology.
In gbf-1(RNAi) oocytes we observed a severely disturbed ER organization.
We corroborated these results by electron microscopy and found that in gbf-1(RNAi) oocytes most of the ER lacked a distinguishable lumen.
Thus, GBF-1 is required for both, ER and Golgi, organization.
Thus, GBF-1 is required for both, ER and Golgi, organization.
Given the strong effect of gbf-1(RNAi) on ER morphology, we checked, whether ERES marked by SEC-16 would also be dispersed.

However, in all analyzed oocytes SEC-16 still localized in marked patches on close to the Golgi, similar to its localization in wild-type or mock-treated animals (Fig. 3C). These data indicate that despite perturbations in ER structure, ERES could still be maintained.
These results are also in agreement with the vesicle accumulation observed on the cis-side of the Golgi in gbf-1(RNAi) oocytes by electron microscopy (Fig. 2D).
GBF-1 is required for ER integrity in oocytes.
(A) gbf-1(RNAi) results in a disorganized ER in oocytes.
The ER appeared dispersed in gbf-1(RNAi).
The ER morphology in agef-1(RNAi) oocytes was not affected, while in gbf-1(RNAi) oocytes the ER was present as dispersed haze.
In gbf-1(RNAi) the ER was disorganized with regions where the lumen was collapsed.
Partial gbf-1 knockdown impairs secretion
As mentioned above, gbf-1(RNAi) worms have a weakened cuticle, which easily bursts, mostly through the vulva.

In addition, we observed that gbf-1(RNAi) embryos were suffering from egg-shell defects (Fig. S3). We noticed that the embryos were not only osmosensitive (Fig. S3A), but in many cases did not even form a complete egg shell (Fig. S3B).
Similar to the reported phenotype in agef-1(RNAi), we also observed a comparable partial effect on CAV-1 secretion in gbf-1(RNAi) oocytes (Fig. 4A).

The yolk protein VIT-2 is synthesized in the gut, secreted into the body cavity and then taken up through receptor-mediated endocytosis into developing oocytes [23]. Both agef-1(RNAi) and gbf-1(RNAi) caused accumulation of yolk protein fused to GFP (VIT-2::GFP) in the intestine (Fig. 4B).

The yolk protein VIT-2 is synthesized in the gut, secreted into the body cavity and then taken up through receptor-mediated endocytosis into developing oocytes [23]. Both agef-1(RNAi) and gbf-1(RNAi) caused accumulation of yolk protein fused to GFP (VIT-2::GFP) in the intestine (Fig. 4B).
Taken together, these data suggest, that GBF-1 plays a role in secretion.

annotation.infon: retrograde vesicle-mediated transport, Golgi to ER|GO:0006890
annotation.text: However, this role is likely indirect through GBF-1's involvement in retrograde transport to the ER.
GBF-1 is required for secretion and endocytosis.
GBF-1 is required for secretion and endocytosis.
(A) GBF-1 and AGEF-1 are required for caveolin secretion in oocytes.
(A) GBF-1 and AGEF-1 are required for caveolin secretion in oocytes.
(B) Endocytosis of yolk protein is impaired in gbf-1(RNAi) worms.
In gbf-1(RNAi) worms a strong accumulation of YP170::GFP in the body cavity was observed in approximately 70% of the worms.
(C) AGEF-1 and GBF-1 are required for efficient secretion of yolk protein.
(C) AGEF-1 and GBF-1 are required for efficient secretion of yolk protein.
Both agef-1(RNAi) and gbf-1(RNAi) caused a buildup of yolk (YP170::GFP) in the intestine (indicated by black arrows).
Both agef-1(RNAi) and gbf-1(RNAi) caused a buildup of yolk (YP170::GFP) in the intestine (indicated by black arrows).
gbf-1(RNAi) causes a reduction in yolk uptake but not in yolk receptor recycling in oocytes

When we analyzed the yolk secretion phenotype in gbf-1(RNAi) worms, we noticed in addition to yolk in the intestinal cells, a robust accumulation of yolk protein in the body cavity (Fig. 4B), indicative of a defect in receptor-mediated endocytosis in oocytes.

When we analyzed the yolk secretion phenotype in gbf-1(RNAi) worms, we noticed in addition to yolk in the intestinal cells, a robust accumulation of yolk protein in the body cavity (Fig. 4B), indicative of a defect in receptor-mediated endocytosis in oocytes.

Therefore, we decided to look more closely at the yolk content in oocytes in gbf-1(RNAi) worms and found that less VIT-2::GFP was taken up into the oocytes, but that the yolk granule size and distribution in the cell was not dramatically altered (Fig. 5A).
We observed yolk accumulation in the body cavity robustly in more than 70% of the gbf-1(RNAi) worms that had been fed for 48 hour, whereas this was rarely seen in mock-treated animals (0-1%).
However, the RME-2::GFP levels at the plasma membrane were undistinguishable between mock treated and gbf-1(RNAi) oocytes (Fig. 5B).
(A) Yolk protein uptake is strongly reduced in gbf-1(RNAi) oocytes.
RAB11.1::GFP labeled recycling endosomes reached the plasma membrane normally in gbf-1(RNAi) oocytes compared to control oocytes.
The endosomal system is affected in the intestine in gbf-1(RNAi) animals

In wild-type animals, RAB-5::GFP was enriched underneath the apical surface lining the gut lumen, while RAB-7::mCherry stains structures a bit further towards the cell center. In addition both markers label smaller endosomal structures throughout the cells (Fig. 6A).

In wild-type animals, RAB-5::GFP was enriched underneath the apical surface lining the gut lumen, while RAB-7::mCherry stains structures a bit further towards the cell center. In addition both markers label smaller endosomal structures throughout the cells (Fig. 6A).

In wild-type animals, RAB-5::GFP was enriched underneath the apical surface lining the gut lumen, while RAB-7::mCherry stains structures a bit further towards the cell center. In addition both markers label smaller endosomal structures throughout the cells (Fig. 6A).
gbf-1(RNAi) caused a marked reduction of the RAB-5 signal (penetrance ranging from 50% to 85% of the worms in independent experiments).
These data suggest that GBF-1 might be required for maintenance of endosome morphology and potentially for efficient endocytic transport in the gut epithelium.

gbf-1(RNAi) caused a marked reduction of the RAB-5 signal (penetrance ranging from 50% to 85% of the worms in independent experiments). More importantly, RAB-7 was present on large interconnected and tubular endosomal structures throughout the cell, which were much brighter and larger than in mock-treated animals.
GBF-1 plays a role in later stages of endocytosis.
(A) The endocytic pathway in the gbf-1(RNAi) intestine is severely disturbed.

The expression of the early endocytic marker RAB-5::GFP was strongly reduced, while late endosomes appeared to form large aggregates as indicated by the presence of RAB-7. These phenotypes were observed in approximately 60%-90% of gbf-1(RNAi) worms compared to >=10% in mock treated worms.
(B) GBF-1 and AGEF-1 are both required for correct secretion from the Golgi.
(B) GBF-1 and AGEF-1 are both required for correct secretion from the Golgi.
GBF-1 is involved in the endocytic pathway in C. elegans.

annotation.infon: retrograde vesicle-mediated transport, Golgi to ER|GO:0006890
annotation.text: We found that GBF-1 performs evolutionary conserved functions of GBF1/garz/Gea1-2 ArfGEF guanine nucleotide exchange factors, namely a role in retrograde transport from the Golgi to the ER, in Golgi maintenance and secretion.

We found that GBF-1 performs evolutionary conserved functions of GBF1/garz/Gea1-2 ArfGEF guanine nucleotide exchange factors, namely a role in retrograde transport from the Golgi to the ER, in Golgi maintenance and secretion.

We found that GBF-1 performs evolutionary conserved functions of GBF1/garz/Gea1-2 ArfGEF guanine nucleotide exchange factors, namely a role in retrograde transport from the Golgi to the ER, in Golgi maintenance and secretion.

In addition, we found that loss of GBF-1, but not of AGEF-1 affects ER morphology. Strikingly, the lumen of the ER was very much reduced, suggesting a role in ER maintenance independent of the reduced secretion capacity from ER exit sites.

In addition, we found that loss of GBF-1, but not of AGEF-1 affects ER morphology. Strikingly, the lumen of the ER was very much reduced, suggesting a role in ER maintenance independent of the reduced secretion capacity from ER exit sites.

We also noticed a secretion defect in gbf-1(RNAi) manifested by CAV-1 being present in internal structures around the nucleus, osmosensitive embryos, a weakened cuticle and accumulation of yolk protein-GFP in intestinal epithelial cells.

We also noticed a secretion defect in gbf-1(RNAi) manifested by CAV-1 being present in internal structures around the nucleus, osmosensitive embryos, a weakened cuticle and accumulation of yolk protein-GFP in intestinal epithelial cells.

We also noticed a secretion defect in gbf-1(RNAi) manifested by CAV-1 being present in internal structures around the nucleus, osmosensitive embryos, a weakened cuticle and accumulation of yolk protein-GFP in intestinal epithelial cells.

We also noticed a secretion defect in gbf-1(RNAi) manifested by CAV-1 being present in internal structures around the nucleus, osmosensitive embryos, a weakened cuticle and accumulation of yolk protein-GFP in intestinal epithelial cells.
Since gbf-1(RNAi) significantly perturbed Golgi morphology, this secretory defect might be secondary to the loss of Golgi integrity.
Since gbf-1(RNAi) significantly perturbed Golgi morphology, this secretory defect might be secondary to the loss of Golgi integrity.
gbf-1 knockdown also caused a defect in endocytosis.

Alternatively, given that gbf-1(RNAi) interferes with Golgi morphology, yolk protein synthesized in the gut epithelium may not have been glycosylated properly and therefore may bind with a somewhat lower affinity to the yolk receptor.
gbf-1 knockdown also caused a defect in endocytosis. However, we found a reduction in yolk protein uptake, which is a receptor-mediated and clathrin-dependent pathway [23].
Consistent with this hypothesis, we found that gbf-1(RNAi) strongly affected RAB-7 positive endosomes and to a lesser extent early RAB-5 positive endosomes in the gut epithelium.
